file-roller looks at file extention not file header to determine type
file-roller looks at file extention not file header to determine type

note.body:
Hi Andre, thank you for the quick reply.
Steps to reproduce as far as the file-roller part is extremely simple:

1. Find a working `tar.gz` file in firefox  (eg: https://en-gb.wordpress.org/latest-en_GB.tar.gz). 
2. Select the "open with" option on firefox and choose to use file-roller
3. File opens successfully.
4. minimise file roller
5. Select the file again and "open with" file-roller a second time. Firefox calls the temporary name of the second download `wordpress-5.3-en_GB.tar-1.gz
6. File roller opens the outer gzip but displays an internal file named 'wordpress-5.3-en_gb.tar-1 which it then fails to open.

Actually, there's an even easier way to reproduce which doesn't need firefox at all:

1. Download or create a working tar.gz file (eg file.tar.gz)
2. Rename to 'file.tar-1.gz'
3. Try opening with file roller and observe that the outer gzip is opened but it then errors when trying to open the inner file.tar-1 as it doesn't recognise the archive.

If you can suggest a distro that would use a later version of file-roller as default (or a way of installing the latest version) then I'd be happy to test against that.

tldr: Why does file-roller care what the file is called rather than deriving its type in the same way the cli command `file` does?

With thanks :)

events.target_title: [regression] Some events are duplicated all over the place to all days in month view

note.body:
Since being reported a year ago this bug still has not been fixed, or a workaround posted. Again: Events occurring on the first day of any month appear inappropriately as duplicates on **every day** of the previous month, in the Month view. In my case, New Year's Day 2020 occurs in every day of December, 2019, in the Month view. 

The Jan 1 New Year's Day entry is not removable in the Gnome-Calendar application. If I find a data file from which I can remove the entry, I will report it here.

```
~$  gnome-calendar --version
gnome-calendar: Version 3.34.2 (repo, not flatpak)
~$  lsb_release -d ; uname -rp ; gnome-shell --version ; echo $XDG_SESSION_TYPE
Description:	Ubuntu 19.10
5.3.0-24-generic x86_64
GNOME Shell 3.34.1
wayland
```

events.target_title: gnome-session-b crashes by stack overflow in libpcre when using fish
5 null deref errors in xpath.c and xpointer.c
Conversation list facelift

note.body:
I'm delighted by the professionality and the effort people are putting in these mockups and discussions. I really appreciate it!

There is just one thing that was never questioned in this whole discussion, which I want to address: the **profile images**. They look nice in the design and also help to better distinguish one mail from another without the dividing line, but I think the design doesn't capture reality as good as we might think.

One weak argument is, that from my experience only very few people have profile images for their contacts on desktops, because platforms like WhatsApp or Facebook where these images can be easily gathered from are more bound to mobile devices than to desktops.

However my main argument is that there is a big usage difference between Chat and E-Mail. E-Mail as the name states originates from letters/mail, and allows potentially everyone to send us a mail (at least if our address is known). While Chats are nearly always a communication from one person to another, where we first have to accept with whom we want to chat (for example by adding them as a friend).  This leads to very different usage of email. The following [statistics](https://de.statista.com/statistik/daten/studie/223876/umfrage/e-mail-typen-im-posteingang/) (you might not be able to access it) unfolds that only 14% of the total emails are personal emails, in other words emails from people that potentially can have a profile picture. All the other emails are auto generated content from companies or organisations like newsletters, confirmation mails, email distributors or payment mails.

You might say that the proposed generated letter based profile images help to bridge this gap. In my opinion they are not nearly as unique and memorable as real images and can be quickly mistaken with each other. When looking at other apps like K9 mail they are just distracting me from the email subject without telling me anything useful.

![K9 Mail Example](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/r_MsrPu8gMsGqwUfUgzs9fgCl8a7Vjfsv03Wgd9RbV0DW9r20oXupKOgKZeg2YpjHw=w1920-h978 "K9 Mail")

So I would prefer to drop the profile images or at least make them optional like K9 does to gain extra space for more important features and avoid confusion.

events.target_title: Consider adding Geary to core or removing Contacts

note.body:
> I believe nothing else in GNOME is using Contacts, so it probably doesn't make sense to keep it otherwise. 

I think doing the opposite would be right. Since Evolution currently combines contacts, calendar and Geary they become far more important than before. Feature-wise Evolution-Contacts offer more options than Gnome-Contacts so it should rather be extended than removed.

Isn't Geary using the same contacts that can be managed with Gnome-Contacts? Also Gnome-Calendar does use contacts for birthdays.

events.target_title: Consider adding Geary to core or removing Contacts

note.body:
> You mean *and email* right? 

I meant: Gnome-Calendar, Gnome-Contacts and Geary. But it doesn't matter if we are talking about the software or their purpose.

> Nobody was talking about removing contacts from Evolution, rather the discussion was removing GNOME Contacts from core-apps as without Geary it has limited utility (hence the alternative suggestion is to bring Gearn *in* to core) 

I wasn't talking about removing contacts form evolution either. All I'm saying is that Gnome-Contacts should rather be improved (since it is less powerful compared to the contact management evolution provides) instead of being removed if Evolution is replaced by Geary as the default email program in GNOME.

If Geary does not replace Evolution I can understand your point why you want to remove Gnome-Contacts. Though if I follow the logic Gnome-Calender should also be removed from the core.

events.target_title: Avoid Broadwayd - GtkEntry popup takes 35s after application startup
Broadwayd - GtkEntry popup takes 35s after application startup

note.body:
I created a merge request from Fredy second patch on the 3-24 branch. https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/merge_requests/1205

events.target_title: Windows build documentation missing Python runtime support

note.body:
In case my good faith is in doubt here:
* If this is resolved in a later version of the GNU Image Manipultion Program than 2.10.12 then you can close this bug
* None of what you just said is documented
* If cross-building the Python headers is needed, it would be helpful if there was a link to instructions for how to do it

The instructions we followed for 2.10.12 were [duplicated here](https://wiki.glimpse-editor.org/index.php?title=Building_Glimpse/Windows) for reference. I can see that a number of edits were made in the last week [(this is the changelog)](https://wiki.gimp.org/index.php?title=Hacking%3ABuilding%2FWindows&diff=1916&oldid=1897) so some time this week I will see if this is resolved for 2.10.14.

events.target_title: Windows build documentation missing Python runtime support

note.body:
>  What a weird thing to say. We don't doubt anyone's "good faith". This is a bug tracker, we are here to fix bugs. :-)

Fair enough, my apologies if I misjudged your response. Since I started the Glimpse fork a not small number of people online have been giving me individually and the project itself hell for doing it. We've just been keeping our heads down and trying to weather the storm, and as a result I sometimes see hostility where there isn't any. Sorry about that! :)

> I am a bit lost here. Are you actually reporting a bug in the software here? I thought you only reported a problem with the documentation.

What I meant here was "if a fix has been made to the build system or a workaround has been found", as that would mean there is no problem with the documentation.

 > If so, I would suggest to look at `m4macros/pythondev.m4` to see how we detect the Python version and headers and at your `config.log`

Will do. I'm running another build now so will paste the output here.

events.target_title: Windows build documentation missing Python runtime support

note.body:
The bit to which I was referring was when you said that `--disable-python` was included to help with demos. If I had known that was the case, I would have understood that not loading Python plug-ins was a downstream bug in our build process and not an upstream documentation bug.

I was also unaware that Python headers had to be cross-compiled from source. I had been trying to make packages in MSYS2 work without success, so it looks like I will need to dedicate some time to puzzling out the cross-compilation. :)

events.target_title: Windows build documentation missing Python runtime support

note.body: I had previously asked this question on IRC FWIW, but unfortunately no one online at the time knew the answer. I'm glad I raised this bug though as it is setting me on the right path.

events.target_title: Windows build documentation missing Python runtime support

note.body:
Okay. So my understanding then is that this is a bug after all.

I will spend time over the next week or so working on the problem. If I come up with a solution I will post a comment here with a link to our docs so you can bring the changes into your own docs. (You may need to do some testing on `master` branch though, as we use tags on `gimp2-10` branch)

events.target_title: Windows build documentation missing Python runtime support

note.body:
I could be mistaken but so long as headers for Python 2 and Python 3 are in the environment then it shouldn't matter if you're using GNU Build System or Meson, both should pick up the dependencies they need.

If GNU Image Manipulation Program 3.0 will have an entirely different plug-in API that breaks compatibility with plug-ins for 2.x, then outside this bug ticket we would certainly be interested in knowing more about that.

events.target_title: Windows build documentation missing Python runtime support

note.body: Okay, so do the `--with-javascript=force --with-lua=force` have any effect at all on the 2.x builds? From what you were saying it sounds like that's a 3.x feature.

events.target_title: Windows build documentation missing Python runtime support

note.body: Indeed. As stated earlier I'm going to set aside some time in the coming week to see if I can get the compiled Python headers to work within MSYS2. I'll update this ticket if I produce an answer :+1:

Just found out about this and wanted to report it. In my case, it was as simple as calculating `2-3` and then added `3` to the front of the result, and got `3-1 = -3`. Note that if I click the number in the calculator history, it works as expected. 3.34.1, Ubuntu 19.10, Czech
![Snímek_z_2019-11-23_02-12-11](/uploads/6b3d3a9746f7ebceaa08d95a726f7efc/Snímek_z_2019-11-23_02-12-11.png)

events.target_title: Wacom stylus screen mode bug.

note.body:
Sadly GIMP (and/or GTK+) isn't entirely predictable when it comes to tablet problems....

I've never had problems with XP-Pen Star 06 [wireless painting tablet](https://www.xp-pen.com/product/49.html) on my GIMP installation (aside from the occasional failure to detect the tablet at all), unfortunately I'm not quite sure I understand the description. Nonetheless, here's a few quick things to check / rule out:

- Screen/window mode. It should definitely be set to "Screen", so this doesn't seem to be the cause....

- Pen/mouse mode. If, for example, you pick up the pen from point A and put it down on point B but the cursor doesn't immediately snap to the new location, then you've got the stylus set on mouse (relative movement) mode. Check your Wacom tablet control panel to be sure it's on Pen (absolute movement) mode.

note.body:
I'm getting a similar problem; I'm using evince 3.34.1, CUPS 2.3.0 under Manjaro, and perhaps most importantly an Epson L120 printer with the .ppd file provided in the [official website](http://download.ebz.epson.net/dsc/search/01/search/?OSC=LX).

I'm trying to print a .pdf file in Chilean 'Oficio' size (215.9x330mm) by defining this custom size within evince, but when I send the job to the printer it reverts to Legal, which is among the default sizes set by the .ppd file, and is larger on the long side — this causes the page to be offset and off the margins even if auto centering is turned off. The new page size can be seen in the Printer Status dialog:

![Screenshot_2019-11-23_03-31-59](/uploads/c370ae41f48b8bffcc8b37a14cac629a/Screenshot_2019-11-23_03-31-59.png)

However, @dngray's suggestion of printing to .ps first and then printing the resulting file in evince works wonders, so at least a workaround seems to exist:

events.target_title: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/shotwell/issues/183
Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)
Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)

note.body:
I executed callgrind and perf, they both report this:
+ Inclusive   Self    Process   Module                  Function
+   49.58%    49.57%  xsltproc  libxml2.so.2.9.1    [.] xmlStrncat
+   48.62%    48.61%  xsltproc  libxml2.so.2.9.1    [.] xmlStrlen

basically meaning that most of the time is used copying strings and measuring strings in my use case.
for the test case, I am going to check.

It seems that maintaing the size of text nodes and the xmlNode could have a huge impact on performance, using some "copy-on-write" or immutable text logic could cut execution time by a big factor

events.target_title: Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)

note.body:
The path is starting under xsltApplySequenceConstructor:
- xsltValueOf => xsltCopyTextString => xsltAddTextString
- xsltCopyText => xsltAddTextString
then
- xsltAddTextString => xmlStrnlen (half of the time)
- xsltAddTextString => xmlNodeAddContent => xmlNodeAddContentLen => xmlStrncat (the other half)

events.target_title: Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)

note.body:
After some debugging, I understand what happens: 
* we use EXSLT and concatenation cache is NULLed any time a EXSLT function is called (cannot grasp why there is code duplication is this region btw), "cur->pswi == xsltExtMarker ==> ctxt->lasttext = NULL"
* we use xsl:variable quite a lot as our XSL is pretty complex, there is only one such "lasttext", but when xsl:variable elements are encountered a new target node is created, and first concatenation empties "lasttext" and when interned string are copied to it "lasttext" is invalidated as well

For problem 1, using systematically xsltAddChild in libexslt could bring the opportunity to ensure that the "lasttext" cache is invalidated properly and thus avoid the cache systematic trashing. Another way is to invalidate only for the few functions that actually do xmlAddChild... my preference goes to ensure that the cache is never trashed
For problem 2, probably need to a few entries, not just one, maybe just 2, top level + first level of xsl:variable

A more impacting solution would be to do some homework in libxml2, supporting a new type of "dynamic text node", which would allow efficient concatenation (putting lasttuse/lasttsize in xmlNode more or less), simplifying drastically all of this. 

If you want I can work on that and try a patch.

events.target_title: Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)

note.body:
Indeed could append text nodes and coalesce them when we are finished with the direct parent node, a single scan per node, gathering sequences of text and replacing them with a single text node for each, linear time.
Possible ?

events.target_title: Performance issue: xsltproc slow when producing text file (9MB)
Performance issue when appending text to a text node

note.body:
As you write, "the signature is still valid, in the time it had been created", but how can be sure? What if attacker had modifyed his local time?

So I suggest to validate certificate using date in "Received" header. 
This should'n affect messages, that were signed few years ago and they will stlill look valid. This solution is also resistant to changing my local time.

Because now i can easily modify date in message header and signature is still valid. See attachment. And i thing, that's not OK.![evolution_smime](/uploads/d4b7f6dc6105280329c9e0b2b91d7588/evolution_smime.png)

events.target_title: In Print -> Image settings, the Center selection is reset when scaling the size.
In Print -> Image settings, the Center selection is reset when scaling the size.

note.body:
Having studied the code, I see that the **various on_*_value_changed** calls cannot distinguish if they are called by the user/GTK directly or are called as a consequence of the adjustment of other Buttons.

For example: When user sets the **Center** to **Both** it will (possibly) need to adjust the values of **Left**, **Top** etc. However, If the user presses the **-** or **+** of **Left** directly, you would like to modify the **Center** value from **Both** to **Vertical**, as only the horizontal part is non-centered anymore.

I assume this conflict can be solved by making **adjust_*_value** (similar as the **on_*_value_changed** functions) which firstly block the trigger, secondly modify the value and finally unblock the trigger.

events.target_title: In Print -> Image settings, the Center selection is reset when scaling the size.

note.body: It seems the signal [value-changed](https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/stable/GtkSpinButton.html#GtkSpinButton-value-changed) is already emitted if the SpinButton gets into focus, but has no value changed. This means that repetitively pressing the Tab key will force an update of each of the value. The image will move due to rounding errors.

events.target_title: wont connect to caldav
Stop using show_all
NetworkManager openconnect fails to connect with immediate failure

note.body:
I have also noticed this issue on Fedora 31. It's working when user in "juniper/nc" mode but stopps forwarding packets after 10-20 minutes. It may be related to something inproperly configured on IVE.

Changing mode to "pulse" makes Linux not to even try to connect. I suspected this could be related to the openconnect execution parameters since CLI works like a charm... always.

[jarekb@madcow ~]$ sudo openconnect -b --protocol=pulse ra.comp.com.pl/compsa
[sudo] hasło użytkownika jarekb: 
Połączono z 91.198.145.110:443
Negocjacja SSL z ra.comp.com.pl
Połączono z HTTPS na ra.comp.com.pl
Otrzymano odpowiedź HTTP: HTTP/1.1 101 Switching Protocols
Proszę podać dane uwierzytelniania użytkownika:
Nazwa użytkownika:jarbazyd
Hasło:
Połączono jako 10.31.96.99, za pomocą SSL, z ESP w trakcie
Kontynuowanie w tle. PID 3323
[jarekb@madcow ~]$ Nawiązano sesję ESP z serwerem


I was about to rise another issue but see it is already here :-) 

Hope someone from NM-OpenConnect devs will look at it... it must be something trivial.

Regards
J.

events.target_title: NetworkManager openconnect fails to connect with immediate failure

note.body:
We looked at it once again and definately the problem is with parsing gateway strings. NM-OpenConnect assumes that all users are connecting to Pulse Server without realm string i.e. ra.comp.com.pl and change this into https://ra.comp.com.pl when executing openconnect with parameters.

Our case is we are usings realm and assigned sign-in paged to it. That is when user connect to ra.comp.com.pl/compa (/compsa is the sign-in page for that realm). As we see whatewer you fill in gateway part of form is truncated to FQDN without URL /compsa at the end. Since we do not have default sign-in page defines Pulse Server returns error "The page you requested could not be found.". I do personally think that we are facing improperly parsed gateway problem here. I think resolution would be to keep whole GATEWAY string as-is and pass it to executable.

Interesting part is that when we use Juniper as protocol everything is parsed properly :-)

Are there any developers reviewing issues here? 

Regards
J.

note.body: To add some more information,  I found this originally when I used a script to toggle between different modes of working and was issuing multiple gnome-extension enable/disable commands in a row. I've noticed that /org/gnome/shell/disabled-extensions is being written to by gnome-shell by gnome-extension but not consistently when multiple gnome-extension commands are written. Additionally neither gnome-tweak not chrome-gnome-shell currently write to /org/gnome/shell/disabled-extensions and only disable by removing item from the /org/gnome/shell/enabled-extensions list.

events.target_title: Cannot see wayland sessions
Cannot see wayland sessions

note.body:
Hi Tim,

This is what I see for both:

`/etc/gdm/custom.conf`:
```
# GDM configuration storage
#
# Note: settings from /etc/sysconfig/displaymanager have a higher priority
#

[daemon]
# Uncomment the line below to force the login screen to use Xorg
#WaylandEnable=false

[security]

[xdmcp]

[chooser]

[debug]
# Uncomment the line below to turn on debugging
#Enable=true
```

`61-gdm.rules`:
```
# disable Wayland on Cirrus chipsets
ATTR{vendor}=="0x1013", ATTR{device}=="0x00b8", ATTR{subsystem_vendor}=="0x1af4", ATTR{subsystem_device}=="0x1100", RUN+="/usr/lib/gdm/gdm-disable-wayland"
# disable Wayland on Hi1710 chipsets
ATTR{vendor}=="0x19e5", ATTR{device}=="0x1711", RUN+="/usr/lib/gdm/gdm-disable-wayland"
# disable Wayland when using the proprietary nvidia driver
DRIVER=="nvidia", RUN+="/usr/lib/gdm/gdm-disable-wayland"
```
FYI My machine is thinkpad x1 extreme

events.target_title: "No stylus found" displayed in GNOME settings on Thinkpad X1 Yoga.
negative margin on window decoration gives "pixman_region32_init_rect: Invalid rectangle passed"
Compose sequences of GTK_MAX_COMPOSE_LEN rejected
negative margin on window decoration gives "pixman_region32_init_rect: Invalid rectangle passed"

note.body:
This happens in any program when using negative margins on the `window > decoration` node; I've not seen it on other CSS nodes. I don't have a need for negative decoration margins, but I haven't ruled out that such a thing might be desirable--I personally disable decorations in all situations.

I'm using Openbox and Compton, but can trigger this assertion under Wayland with Weston as well.

Let meeting invitation show HTML version of DESCRIPTION, if available
Let meeting invitation show HTML version of DESCRIPTION, if available

note.body:
Sure. I stored the mail as a mbox and replaced/removed "critical" content. I imported the edited mbox and it worked for me. I get the same behaviour as for the original message.

[meeting_of_chancelors.mbox](/uploads/f8c197ef0bc374fdbb40d5eb7241d315/meeting_of_chancelors.mbox)

events.target_title: Let meeting invitation show HTML version of DESCRIPTION, if available

note.body:
Ok. I understand the problem, that it would be a major change in evolution to support HTML in event descriptions and therefore it would be hard to add this feature.

Nevertheless, my main concern is the display of the mail and not how it is displayed in the calendar. Would it be possible to display the HTML part of the message when there exists one or to add the option to switch to the html part?

events.target_title: Let meeting invitation show HTML version of DESCRIPTION, if available

note.body:
Yes the web interface shows the mail in the correct format and it is possible to add the event via the web interface. The description of this event looks fine in the web interface and in the description of the evolution calendar. Exchange seems to do a conversion of the HTML part to a text part. (Evolution might also do this, but I do not know the details here.)

If I accept the invitation in Evolution then I get the same description text for the event as in the DESCRIPTION text/calender part of the mbox.

The main problem is probably that the Microsoft exchange server provides a really bad formatting for the text part of the message. It should be reported to them as a bug in there software. Do you know a good place where such a bug report could be done?

Nevertheless, the handling of such mails can probably be improved in Evolution. I see two possible options:

1. (More hacky approach and fix the bugs of other people): If there is an text/calendar part in a message and there is an text/html part in the message, then do not use the description field in the text/calendar part. Use the text/html part instead and perform a html to text conversion for the description of the event.

2. Provide the user with the ability to select different parts of the message for the display. Either via a right click menu or a drop down combo box between the header of the message and the content. E.g. "Display type: {plain, html, calendar}" where calendar would be the default.

For me option two would be totally fine.

events.target_title: Let meeting invitation show HTML version of DESCRIPTION, if available

note.body:
>  In fact, a multipart/alternative part with text/plain and text/html already have this in the context menu.

I could not find this menu in the context so I think we have here a bug in evolution. I modified the mbox such that it does not contain the text/calendar section. After the import I got a selection of the alternative part. So this section is missing in the context menu for the text/calendar display.

The context menu for the message with text/plain, text/html and text/calendar:
![Context](/uploads/5df4e5a1c5bb91477b7e907152e9ed13/Context.png)

The context menu for the message with text/plain, text/html:
![Context_no_calendar](/uploads/e552a60301609b072f1e75c4bb8e288c/Context_no_calendar.png)

Should I file a bug for this?

events.target_title: Let meeting invitation show HTML version of DESCRIPTION, if available

note.body:
Thank you for the clarification.

Yes, then I would like to request this feature. :)

events.target_title: Let meeting invitation show HTML version of DESCRIPTION, if available

note.body: P.S.: Thank you for the patience in figuring this out.

events.target_title: PNG gAMA chunk is silently ignored

note.body:
This is part of the PNG specification and GIMP should implement the specification right. PNG's specification is remarkably simple compared to some other formats. In particular the specification tells that if a gAMA chunk is present and the chunks iCCP, sRGB and cHRM are absent, then the application has to take gAMA into account. GIMP should do all its possible to render the image as close as possible to what it is supposed to look like. The gamma Display Filter option seems to prove that this could be programmed fairly easily in GIMP, and would not require any resampling of the image.

If it is too hard to achieve (because the program GIMP may not know what is actual effective gamma (the gamma from the channel values sent to the operating system to the actual pixel on the display) ), there should at least be some /coherence/ between the possibilities. By coherence I precisely mean the following:  if the user is able to set their display and os settings so that an sRGB image is displayed right, then all other color modes should also display right as per the PNG specification.

As a matter of fact, there are computer rendered images that are encoded with gamma=1 (they use a linear color coding).

events.target_title: Printing two A5 pages onto A4 pages results in scaling the A5 pages to roughly A6 size
300dpi text scan very slow document rendering/displaying
300dpi text scan very slow document rendering/displaying

note.body:
@ionuke Wow! My case is different. My scanner is scanning fast, about 4s. It is linear and straight forward. No problem. However, the transmission is very slow. About 60s. The problem starts after the scanner has already scanned the document. It receives the scanned document slowly. It is linear. I think in my case it is a "transmission" problem, e.g. a problem in the transmission protocol, too small buffers, ... 

I could not try the new version.

LFS problem: If files are >2GB, size is shown as negative number

note.body:
Here it is:

```
$ rpm -q meld
meld-3.20.1-3.fc31.noarch
```

Is this issue somewhere on gitlab?

events.target_title: LFS problem: If files are >2GB, size is shown as negative number

note.body:
Hope this helps:

```
$ truncate  a/a --size 4G
$ truncate  b/b --size 3G
$ truncate  a/b --size 2G
$ truncate  b/a --size 1G
$ meld a b
```
And there you go, Fedora 31, up to date, on my home in XFS:

![image](/uploads/8f59e084d6463df3e2d4823b67551a47/image.png)

events.target_title: LFS problem: If files are >2GB, size is shown as negative number

note.body: No problem. And glad to help

events.target_title: Overlap with dash to dock

note.body: The overlapping occurs only when "Intelligent autohide" in Dash to Dock settings is enabled. You can move icons and get rid of the "problem" but unfortunately, when you log in again the icons return to the default position.
